Award.AwardTitle: Science Policy Research Report: Advising the President on Science Policy and the Role of the President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
The President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology (PCAST), created in 1990 under President George H.W. Bush, is an independent advisory committee. Comprised of approximately 20 civilian members with diverse backgrounds in academic research, industry, and military service, PCAST was co-chaired by the president's science advisor. PCAST provided advice related to science, technology, and innovation: jobs and economic growth, public health, national and domestic security, energy and the environment, STEM education, emerging technologies and research, and other specialized topics of value to the president and provides timely recommendations to address urgent public policy challenges. PCAST played a critical role in the development of federal research initiatives and reviewed large-scale government science and technology programs and ensured the president had the most up-to-date scientific and technical information to make policy decisions.

While always having the same goal during each Presidential administration, the membership, operation, activities, and impact of PCAST changed, reflecting the needs of the administration's highest priority policy issues. This science policy research report examines the role and influence of PCAST over the last four administrations of Presidents George H.W. Bush, Bill Clinton, George W. Bush, and Barack Obama. The project compiles a database of the demographics of PCAST members including their gender, ethnicity, areas of expertise, and career background. Review activities of PCAST including reports, meetings, and newsworthy events are analyzed to assess PCAST's impact on science and technology policy and decision-making, with suggestions for best practices and actionable recommendations to improve PCAST in the current and future administrations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project compiled and analyzed the membership, activities, and policy impact of the President’s Council of Advisors on Science and Technology (PCAST)—an independent advisory committee consisting of roughly 20 scientists, engineers, doctors, and other individuals with technical backgrounds. The project resulted in an exhaustive documentation of materials from PCAST’s public record from its creation in 1990 by President George H.W. Bush to its last chartered meeting in January 2017 under President Barack Obama. This information includes biographic details and analysis of its memberships; a timeline of operational changes to PCAST, including executive orders and legislation impacting its functions; PCAST budget and meeting history and its public interactions with the president and vice president; all materials published by the council, including letters and reports, summarized and categorized by research subject; and an examination of PCAST’s influence on federal science, technology, and innovation policy available in the public record. This information was assembled together into a searchable spreadsheet that will be publicly available on the Baker Institute website. Analysis from the project, as well as a literature review of both news items and policy reports addressing PCAST, were used to develop policy recommendations for the role and organization of PCAST. The report is being disseminated to policymakers and the broader science and technology policy community through a publicly available policy report, conference presentations, and peer-reviewed journal articles.
